data.title: Laura Wade West
data.meta_description: Business and healthcare attorney Laura Wade West, in brief.
data.text:
Home: New York, NY. Â Age: Approaching the big 4-0. Â Birthplace: Tulsa, OK. Â Profession: Attorney specializing in healthcare and business; volunteer and non-profit director. Â Pronouns: She/Her/Hers. Â Alma mater: University of Miami School of Law; University of Kansas.Â Languages spoken: English and French.â

Current project: Currently increasing my volunteer work and non-profit board service, focused on womenâs health, mental health, and access to healthcare for elderly adults in New York City. Â Recent recognition: âYou are the best godmother!â Â Recent professional development: Admitted to the New York Bar, my third jurisdiction. Â Latest contribution to others: Taking on additional volunteer work and board assignments to contribute to my community. Â Recent travel or adventure: Roland-Garros! Â Last book read: Fresh Water for Flowers, by Valerie Perrin.â

Moral compass: The Bible. Â How do you define a perfect friendship? True friends are there for the highs and lows and unafraid to tell the truth. Â How do you define an ideal business relationship? Respect, cooperation, and teamwork. Â What natural talent have you neglected? Playing the piano.â

What occupation, other than your own, do you most admire? So many: artists, scientists, performers. Â How do you relieve stress? Meditation, working out, mindfulness. â

What was your first paying job? Suzuki-trained piano teacher. Â What was your favorite college course? From Goddesses to Witches (created by my favorite professor, Dr. Leslie Tuttle). Â What was your favorite childhood toy or game? UNO on snow days with my siblings! Â What book have you repeatedly read? Franny and Zooey, by J.D. Salinger. Â What movie have you repeatedly watched? Somethingâs Gotta Give (coastal grandma chic). Â Whatâs prominently featured on your home or office wall? A 1980 work by Cuban artist Dionisio Perkins. Â Besides your parents, who has had the greatest influence on your life? My grandmother, Betty Jo Hall.â

What change would you like to see in the world?

Spread inclusiveness over divisiveness. â

What widely held belief do you reject? The American notion of âpulling oneself up by the bootstraps.â Â Â What mega-trend most excites you? Women normalizing openness by speaking about their health and personal struggles. Â What mega-trend most concerns you? The erosion of womenâs rights and reproductive rights in the US. â

What actor would you choose to play you in the movie about your life? Margot Robbie. Â As a kid, what did you first want to be when you grew up? This changed weekly, but I remember: doctor, teacher, concert pianist. Â How would you choose to spend tomorrow, if you knew it was your last day on earth? With my husband and family, soaking up the time together outdoors with a nice bottle of wine. Â What advice would you give your younger self? Stop worrying; it will all work out.â
